fields.content:
The Shakespeare Census attempts to locate and describe all extant copies of all editions of Shakespeare’s works through 1700, excluding the folios. We include all items attributed to Shakespeare in print during the period, but not those attributed to him only by modern scholarship. We exclude the Restoration adaptations. The census currently includes records for {copy_count} copies.

The initial data has been derived from ESTC, and these copies are listed as unverified (⃠) until their existence has been confirmed on site (✓). We welcome contributions and corrections to copy-specific information from users via the Contact page.

Each copy in the Shakespeare Census has been given a unique identifier, the SC #, which can be used in references and citations. Please cite the Shakespeare Census as follows:

Shakespeare Census. Ed. Adam G. Hooks and Zachary Lesser. Created 2018. Accessed {current_date}. <http://www.shakespearecensus.org>
This project is modelled on and extends the groundbreaking bibliographic work of Henrietta C. Bartlett. It builds on and incorporates the information in A Census of Shakespeare’s Plays in Quarto 1594-1709, compiled by Bartlett and Alfred W. Pollard (1916), which was revised and extended by Bartlett alone (1939). In addition, Bartlett also compiled Mr. William Shakespeare: Original and Early Editions of his Quartos and Folios (1922).

We are very grateful to our advisory board for their help in creating the Shakespeare Census:

Heidi Brayman (University of California, Riverside)
Meaghan Brown (Folger Shakespeare Library)
Lukas Erne (University of Geneva)
Mitch Fraas (University of Pennsylvania Libraries)
Sonia Massai (King’s College London)
Jay Moschella (Boston Public LIbrary)
Andrew Murphy (University of St Andrew’s)
Aaron Pratt (Harry Ransom Center, University of Texas)
Emma Smith (Oxford University)
Adam Smyth (Oxford University)
Heather Wolfe (Folger Shakespeare Library)

The following references appear in the Shakespeare Census. We also list the initials of scholars who have examined a particular copy and transcribed information from it, where that information is not obvious.

AGH // Adam G. Hooks

Bartlett 1916 // Henrietta C. Bartlett and Alfred W. Pollard, A census of Shakespeare's plays in quarto, 1594-1709 (New Haven: Yale UP, 1916).

Bartlett 1939 // Henrietta C. Bartlett and Alfred W. Pollard, A census of Shakespeare's plays in quarto, 1594-1709, rev. Bartlett (New Haven: Yale UP, 1939).

DEEP // Alan B. Farmer and Zachary Lesser, DEEP: Database of Early English Playbooks.

Erne & Singh // Lukas Erne and Devani Singh, Shakespeare in Geneva: Early Modern English Books (1475-1700) at the Martin Bodmer Foundation (Geneva: Editions Ithaque, 2018).

ESTC // English Short Title Catalogue.

Greg // W.W. Greg, A Bibliography of the English Printed Drama to the Restoration, 4 vols. (London: Bibliographical Society, 1939-59)

LE // Lukas Erne

STC // A Short-Title Catalogue of Books Printed in England, Scotland, & Ireland and of English Books Printed Abroad, 1475-1640, 2nd edition, ed. A.W. Pollard, G. R. Redgrave, W. A. Jackson, F. S. Ferguson, and Katharine F. Pantzer, 3 vols. (London: Bibliographical Society, 1976-91)

Wing // Donald Wing, ed., Short-Title Catalogue of Books Printed in England, Scotland, Ireland, Wales, and British America, and of English Books Printed in Other Countries, 1641-1700, 2nd edition, 4 vols. (New York: MLA, 1972-98).

ZL // Zachary Lesser

When entering information about your copy, please follow these guidelines. Inevitably there is overlap among these fields, and different libraries catalogue this information differently. Adhering to these guidelines will allow us to achieve as much uniformity as possible in the Shakespeare Census, although we understand that the unique characteristics of particular copies may necessitate some deviation. Use your best judgment.

Provenance information: any information regarding the history of ownership and chain of custody of the copy, along with descriptions of markings that identify the same.

Marginalia: handwritten annotations, notes, and other markings found anywhere in the book, but excluding, for example, inscriptions and autographs that belong in the provenance field.

Binding: description of the binding (materials, decoration, etc.)

Binder: name of the binder where known.

Bookplates: description of any bookplates present in the book; this information should be recorded here and not repeated in Provenance information.

Bookplate location: location of bookplates; if more than one bookplate is present, please briefly indicate parenthetically which location corresponds to which bookplate.

Other copy-specific details: please record any other relevant details of the copy not recorded elsewhere in the record, including: missing or added leaves, repairs, bound-with information, and general condition notes. This field may include anything you think is important to users and illuminates this specific copy of the edition.
